journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Continuum thermo-electro-mechanical model for electrostrictive elastomers

article-meta.aff: 1PERCRO Laboratory, Scuola Superiore Sant’Anna, Pisa, Italy
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Modena and Reggio Emilia, Modena, Italy
3Department of Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering, University of Bologna, Bologna, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Rocco Vertechy, Scuola Superiore Sant’Anna, PERCRO Laboratory, Via Alamanni 13b, Ghezzano, San Giuliano Terme, 56100 Pisa, Italy. Email: r.vertechy@sssup.it

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on: ASME 2011 Conference on Smart Materials, Adaptive Structures and Intelligent Systems (SMASIS), Symposium on Modeling, Simulation and Control: Part 1

abstract.p: This article presents a finite-deformation fully-coupled thermo-electro-elastic continuum model that is suited for the analysis, design, and control of solid-state transduction devices based on electrostrictive elastomers. In the model, electrostrictive elastomers are considered as isotropic modified-entropic hyperelastic dielectrics that deform in response to a simultaneous combination of electrical, thermal, and mechanical stimuli. The model is thermodynamically consistent and comprises general balance equations, which do not require the postulation of any force or stress tensor of electrical origin, together with phenomenological invariant-based constitutive relations, which necessitate the minimum number of material parameters to be determined via experimental tests only. Comparison with existing theories and experimental results are provided that validate the proposed thermo-electro-elastic model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Electrostrictive elastomers (EEs) are a special kind of “electroactive polymeric material” whose electrical and structural behaviors are highly nonlinear and strongly coupled. In essence, they are soft rubber-like dielectric solids with high electric susceptibility that experience large finite deformations in response to applied electric fields, while they alter the existing electrostatic fields in response to the deformations undergone. Practical EEs are polyurethanes (Guillot and Balizer, 2003; Zhang et al., 1997; Zhenyi et al., 1994), ferroelectric polymers (Bauer et al., 2006; Zhang et al., 1998), graft elastomers (Su et al., 2000), silicone and polyacrylate (AR) elastomers (Kofod et al., 2003; Ludeelerd et al., 2010; Mathew et al., 2006; Pelrine et al., 1998, 2000), styrene–butadiene rubber (SBR) and styrene–isoprene–styrene (SIS) rubber (Ludeelerd et al., 2010; Nam et al., 2007), ethylene–propylene rubber (EPR) (Nam et al., 2007), polyisoprene rubber (NR) (Nam et al., 2007; Saad and Younan, 1995), liquid crystal elastomers (Lehmann et al., 2001), interpenetrating-polymer-network elastomers and nanostructured rubber (Ha et al., 2007; Shankar et al., 2007; Zhang et al., 2010), as well as a number of other elastomeric composites employing either conducting, semiconducting, or ferroelectric particles as fillers (Carpi and De Rossi, 2005; Kunanuruksapong and Sirivat, 2008; Liu and Shaw, 2001; Puvanatvattana et al., 2006; Yuse et al., 2011). Typical stresses and strains that can be induced in EEs via electrical activation are as follows (Madden et al., 2004; Pelrine et al., 1998; Su et al., 2000): 2 MPa and 11% for polyurethanes, 54 MPa and 7% for ferroelectric elastomers, 4 MPa and 4% for graft elastomers, 3 MPa and 120% for silicone elastomers, 7 MPa and 380% for polyacrylate elastomers, and 1 MPa and 4% for liquid crystal elastomers. Typical rates of such electrically induced strains are larger than 1000%/s for almost all EEs (Madden et al., 2004).

Thanks to the peculiar electro-mechanical coupling, along with the intrinsic compliance, lightness, malleability, easy manufacturability, and low cost, EEs are perfectly suited for the development of novel solid-state mechatronic transducers that are more resilient, lightweight, integrated, economic, and disposable than traditional devices obtainable via conventional material technologies. Practical transduction devices that can be developed using EEs are as follows (Bar-Cohen, 2004; Carpi et al., 2008; Dubowsky et al., 2008; Kim and Tadokoro, 2007; Nalwa, 1995; Nam et al., 2007; O’Halloran et al., 2008): compliant muscle-like actuators, compact and portable Braille displays, distributed force/displacement sensors, solid-state electrical energy harvester/generators, and large solid-state loudspeakers. Potential applications are in the field of machine interfaces for human assistance and entertainment, safe and low-cost robotics, as well as disposable and consumable mechatronics.

Similar to the majority of rubber-like materials, many EEs feature a prevalent entropic behavior that makes them additionally exhibit significant thermo-elastic and electro-caloric heating/cooling effects. As a result, the aforementioned electro-elastic response of EEs is rather sensitive to temperature and, more generally, to specific thermodynamic loads and constraints. For instance, contractions of more than 10% and dielectric constant increase by more than 20% can be induced through heating in many elastomeric dielectrics such as NR, SBR, SIS, polyacrylate elastomers, and ferroelectric polymers (Joule, 1859; Kunanuruksapong and Sirivat, 2008; Neese et al., 2008; Treloar, 2005); adiabatic temperature changes of more than 5°C can be induced through elastic deformation in most elastomeric materials (Joule, 1859; Treloar, 2005); isothermal entropy changes of more than 55 J/(kg K) and adiabatic temperature changes of more than 12°C can be induced through electrical excitation in ferroelectric polymers (Neese et al., 2008).

Owing to such a complicated thermo-electro-mechanical (TEM) response, the accurate analysis, design, and control of practical transducers based on EEs are very challenging problems that require the availability of fully coupled multiphysics models. To date, a number of different formulations, which are based on diverse interaction models, postulates, and solution methods, have been proposed in the literature for the study of the electro-elastic deformations of EEs (Becker, 1964; Bustamante et al., 2009; Hutter and Van De Ven, 1978; Larmor, 1897; Livens, 1926; Lorentz,1916; Panofsky and Phillips, 1955; Pao, 1978; Penfield and Haus, 1967; Robinson, 1975). In particular: (1) some authors directly assumed a special expression for the electrically induced body force and/or stress tensor and simply added them to the continuum balance law of linear mechanical momentum (Dorfmann and Ogden, 2005; Green and Naghdi, 1995; Hutter, 1975; Toupin, 1963); (2) other authors postulated elementary models, such as charges and dipoles, which characterize the macroscopic behavior of the polarized material (Fano et al., 1960; Hutter, 1977; Pao and Hutter, 1975; Penfield and Haus, 1967; Tiersten and Tsai, 1972), thus deriving an expression of the electrically induced body force and/or stress tensor from them; (3) other authors postulated that the interaction at the microscopic scale is characterized by electrons moving in aether, thus obtaining the electrically induced force and/or stress tensor by a statistical averaging process (De Groot and Suttorp, 1972; Eringen and Maugin, 1990; Lax and Nelson, 1971); (4) other authors assumed a special form of the global energy balance from which the coupled balance laws of mass, momenta (directly including the electrically induced forces and/or stress tensor), and electricity are obtained by imposing certain invariance properties (Bobbio, 2000; Chu et al., 1966; Heaviside, 1893–1912; McMeeking and Landis, 2005; Moller, 1972; Toupin, 1956); and (5) other authors assumed a special form of the electric enthalpy from which the coupled balance laws of linear momentum (directly including the electrically induced forces and/or stress tensor) and electricity are obtained via some variational principle (Bustamante et al., 2009; Ericksen, 2007; Grindlay, 1966; McMeeking et al., 2007; Suo et al., 2008; Trimarco, 2009; Yang and Batra, 1995). All these formulations, however, do not account for the practical variation of the electro-elastic response of the EE that may be induced by thermal effects. Very recently, a thermo-electro-elastic model has been proposed by Liu et al. (2011) and Sheng et al. (2011), which however: (1) only applies to a special class of materials, typically identified with the name “dielectric elastomers” (DEs), which essentially are specific EEs having dielectric properties independent of deformation (Carpi et al., 2008); (2) completely neglects the volumetric thermal expansion of the materials, which is usually important in EEs and DEs as well; (3) completely neglects thermo-elastic and electro-caloric heating/cooling effects, which can be significant in EEs and DEs as well; and (4) can only be used to simulate isothermal processes at known temperatures.

In this context, this article presents a finite-deformation thermo-electro-elastic continuum model that is suited for the study of general EEs, which are isotropic in their undeformed and electrically deactivated state and which may become anisotropic upon mechanical and/or electrical loading. As a particular case, the model also applies to DEs. In the model, the EE material is considered as an entropic hyperelastic dielectric that deforms in response to a simultaneous combination of electrical, mechanical, and thermal loads. The proposed model can be considered as (1) the thermodynamic extension of the electro-elastic formulations proposed by Toupin (1956), Hutter and Van De Ven (1978), Eringen and Maugin (1990), and McMeeking and Landis (2005); and (2) the electrostatic extension of the entropic thermo-elastic theories proposed by Chadwick and Creasy (1984) and Holzapfel and Simo (1996). Specifically, the model comprises general balance equations, which do not require the postulation of any force or stress tensor of electrical origin, together with phenomenological invariant-based isotropic constitutive relations (Pennisi and Trovato, 1987; Smith, 1971; Spencer, 1971), which require the minimum number of material parameters to be determined via experimental tests only.

Following the description of this thermo-electro-elastic model, some connections are made with the electro-elastic formulations previously reported by Toupin (1956), Pao (1978), Hutter and Van De Ven (1978), Eringen and Maugin (1990), Dorfmann and Ogden (2005), McMeeking and Landis (2005, 2007), and Landau and Lifshitz (1960). Finally, experimental results acquired via electro-mechanical tests performed on a particular DE sample are presented in order to highlight the differences of the proposed thermo-electro-elastic theory with respect to the formulation recently introduced by Liu et al. (2011) and Sheng et al. (2011).

sec.title: Problem definition and kinematics
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 1, consider a closed and electrically isolated thermodynamic system
B
that is subjected to an inhomogeneous (absolute) temperature field Θ and that comprises dielectric and conducting bodies as well as free space. In the system, both dielectric and conducting bodies can move and deform under the action of externally applied loads of mechanical, electrical, and thermal origin. During such body motions and deformations, the physical region occupied by the considered TEM system
B
does not remain fixed, but it moves and deforms accordingly. Under the assumption of “closed and electrically isolated thermodynamic system”, while the aforementioned body motions and deformations occur, (1) no mass can enter or leave the boundary of
B
, (2) energy (in the form of work or heat) can cross the boundary of
B
, and (3) no interaction occurs between the electrical charges that lay within
B
and those outside (i.e. the boundary of
B
either is electrically shielded from its exterior or has an infinite extent).

caption.p: TEM system: reference, intermediate, and actual configuration.

sec.p:
In this context, define with ℑ a known reference (fixed) frame with respect to which the motions and deformations of
B
are measured (with
B
specifically indicating the current deformed configuration of the considered TEM system that is subjected to the possibly inhomogeneous actual temperature field Θ). Moreover, identify with
B
0
the (initial) stress-free reference configuration of the same TEM system at an homogeneous reference temperature Θ0, and with
B
Θ
an intermediate (imaginable) thermal stress-free configuration resulting from the free thermal expansion (of the same TEM system) that is induced by the temperature field Θ about the reference configuration
B
0
.

Regarding system kinematics, for any arbitrary time instant
t ≥ 0
, consider a general material point P (i.e. a particle) belonging to the considered TEM system
B
and indicate with X, XΘ(X,t), and x(X,t) (where x(X,t=0)≡X), the position vectors expressing the location (relative to the origin O of ℑ) occupied by P when the TEM system is in its reference (
B
0

B

), and actual (
B
) configurations, respectively. Then, with reference to Figure 1, the following definitions hold

) Finger deformation (or left Cauchy–Green) tensor.

Regarding TEM system loadings, the physical space contained within
B
features a distribution of electric charges (for instance, in the form of free and injected electrons or ions) with densities ϕ(x,t) and ϕγ(x,t), respectively defined per unit volume dv of
B
and per unit area ds of the actual physical surface γ(t) (for instance, a conducting electrode), and a distribution of matter with mass density ρ(x,t), defined per unit volume dv of
B
. The same physical space is also subjected to purely mechanical loads represented by a body force field (such as the gravity field) b(x,t), defined per unit volume dv of
B
and by a traction vector tγ(x,t), defined per unit area ds of the actual physical surface γ(t) (for instance, a body boundary); purely thermal loads represented by a heat source field (such as a reservoir of heat) R(x,t), defined per unit volume dv of
B
and a heat flux vector qγ(x,t), defined per unit area ds of the actual physical surface γ(t) (for instance, a body boundary).

sec.title: Basic balance equations
sec.p:
Consider an arbitrary but closed subsystem of
B
, hereafter called
B
*
, which (for every time instant t > 0) is identified by the volume Ω(t) and bounded by the closed surface
∂ Ω ( t )
having unit normal n(x,t). In Figure 1, one of these possible subsystems is indicated with a gray dash-dotted line. Irrespective of the specific TEM response of the substances contained therein, in the framework of classical (Newtonian) mechanics and classical (Maxwellian) electrostatics, the evolution of such an arbitrary subsystem
B
*
is governed by the following balance relations (expressed in global form)

where
u
·
( x , t )

u

∂ Ω ( t )
; and E(x,t) and D(x,t) are the electric field and electric displacement acting within
B
*

B
*
, whereas the area S(t) is any arbitrary open surface belonging to
B
*
. The electric field and displacement contained in equations (11) and (12) are related by the well-known relation
where ε0 is the dielectric constant of the vacuo (namely, ε0 = 8.85 × 10−12 F/m) and P(x,t) is the electric polarization.

Relation (8) is the conservation of mass equation expressing that no mass can enter or leave the closed boundary
∂ Ω ( t )
. Equations (9) and (10) represent the balances of linear and angular mechanical momentum, respectively expressing that all the forces acting within Ω(t) as well as on
∂ Ω ( t )
and γ(t) need to be equivalent to a system of zero resultant force and zero resultant torque. Equations (11) and (12) are the forms of Faraday’s and Gauss’s laws holding whenever any existing magnetic field is stationary and which govern the evolution of all the electrostatic phenomena occurring within
B
*
.
Given the stress theorem

B
*
is an arbitrary subsystem of
B

Note that the boundary condition of equation (17) that derives from equation (10) is not reported since it is identically satisfied (Abraham and Marsden, 1978; Eringen, 1980; Truesdell and Noll, 1992).

sec.title: Conservation of total energy
sec.p:
For the arbitrary closed subsystem
B
*
, energy can cross the boundary
∂ Ω ( t )
in the form of heat, electrical work, and mechanical work. Differently than
B
, any arbitrary subsystem
B
*
is not electrically isolated, and thus, interactions may exist between the electrical charges that lay within the volume Ω(t) and those outside, which certainly need to be accounted for in the energy balance of
B
*
. According to a fundamental result of potential theory (Livens, 1926; Stratton, 1941), the electric potential
ϕ
(t) at any interior point of Ω(t) remains unaffected if we replace the charges outside the boundary
∂ Ω ( t )
with an equivalent single layer of charges with the following surface density

Thus, the balance of TEM energy of
B
*
can simply be written by considering the equivalent electrically isolated subsystem
B
+
as depicted in Figure 2. Accordingly, the balance of total energy (i.e. the first law of thermodynamics) for the arbitrary TEM subsystem
B
+
(and equivalently for
B
*
) reads as

sec.title: Entropy inequality principle
sec.p:
In addition to equation (38), complete description of the energy transfer occurring across the arbitrary subsystem
B
*
also requires the non-negativeness of the total entropy that is produced during any admissible TEM process. In mathematical terms, this can be stated by the inequality
where Θ(x,t) and η(x,t) are the temperature and entropy fields, respectively.

Using Reynold’s transport and Gauss’ divergence theorems along with equation (15), by considering that
B
*
is an arbitrary subsystem of
B
, equation (40) yields the following local form valid within Ω(t) −γ(t)
along with the following boundary conditions on γ(t)
Equation (41) is well-known in modern thermodynamic research as the Clausius–Duhem inequality.

For the next usage, it is convenient to rewrite equation (41) in a different form. First, introduce the standard Legendre transformation (Abraham and Marsden, 1978; Eringen, 1980; Truesdell and Noll, 1992)
where Ψ(x,t) is a free-energy density of deformation and polarization, such that the first law of thermodynamics (i.e. equation (38)) becomes
Then, considering that heat does not flow against a temperature gradient, that is
and using equation (44), equation (41) reduces to

which can be considered as the Clausius–Planck inequality for a general TEM system
B
.

sec.title: Constitutive equations
sec.p:
Equations (15) to (19) and (44) with the boundary conditions given by equations (20), (21), and (39) are the universal balance equations that govern the evolution of any general TEM system
B
irrespective of the specific material properties and responses of the (dielectric and conducting) substances contained therein. Considering the thermal loads R(x,t) and qγ(x,t), the electrical loads ϕ(x,t) and ϕγ(x,t), and the mechanical loads b(x,t) and tγ(x,t) as known quantities, the remaining field variables ρ(x,t), u(x,t), σ(x,t),
ϕ
(x,t), E(x,t), P(x,t), q(x,t), Θ(x,t), η(x,t), and Ψ(x,t) amount to 23 scalar variables, whereas equations (15) to (19) and (44) consist of only nine scalar equations. Problem solution then requires additional 14 scalar equations, hereafter called constitutive equations, which specifically account for the peculiar TEM properties and behaviors of the bodies contained within
B
.

However, the needed constitutive equations are not all independent of each other. Indeed, selecting u(x,t),
ϕ
(x,t), and Θ(x,t) as the independent variables and assuming the heat flux vector and the free-energy density (i.e. four scalar equations) as being general functions of the deformation gradient F given by equation (4), of the electric field E given by equation (18), and of the absolute temperature Θ(x,t) along with its gradient (
∇ Θ
), namely
then equation (45) reduces to
which, for any admissible TEM process, gives
that is to say the independency of Ψ from ∇Θ (i.e. Ψ = Ψ(F,E,Θ)), along with the remaining 10 scalar constitutive equations

That is, the solution of any specific TEM problem only requires the definition of a heat flux vector q(F,E,∇Θ,Θ) and of a free-energy function Ψ(F,E,Θ) for the peculiar materials contained within
B
.

In the following subsections, specific forms of q(F,E,∇Θ,Θ) and Ψ(F,E,Θ) are obtained for isotropic thermo-electro-elastic polymeric dielectrics (ITEEPDs), which do not feature any internal dissipation and whose elastic and polarization responses are of entropic origin mainly.

sec.title: Free-energy function for ITEEPDs
sec.p: Introduce the specific heat capacity per unit reference volume at constant deformation (i.e. F = const) and at constant electric field (i.e. E = const), namely

which is defined as a positive function of the absolute temperature Θ only, and which corresponds to the amount of energy that is required to produce a unit increase in temperature of a unit volume of the TEM system
B
by keeping the deformation and the electric field fixed. Then, assuming a temperature change

between a selected reference state
B
0
at the reference temperature Θ0 and the current state
B
at the actual temperature Θ (see Figure 1), the change in internal energy and entropy associated with any admissible TEM process can be determined by respectively integrating the second and third side of equation (53) with respect to temperature, that is
with U0(F,E) = U(F,E,Θ0) and
with η0(F,E) = η(F,E,Θ0). Then, by plugging equations (55) and (56) into equation (43) and by considering the Legendre transformation at the reference temperature Θ0, namely
where Ψ0(F,E) = Ψ(F,E,Θ0), the free-energy function Ψ(F,E,Θ) introduced in equation (47) assumes the following form
Taking (for simplicity) a constant heat capacity with respect to the reference temperature Θ0, that is
and assuming a liquid-like behavior of the considered ITEEPDs, and thus a modified-entropic electro-elastic response such that

where α0 and κ0 are the (linear) thermal expansion and specific bulk modulus coefficients of the ITEEPDs at the reference temperature Θ0, whereas ζ is an additional dimensionless constant material parameter, equation (58) simplifies into

Furthermore, assuming an isotropic electro-elastic response of the considered ITEEPDs, owing to the representation theorem for invariants (Eringen, 1980; Truesdell and Noll, 1992), the free energy Ψ0(F,E) that is required in equation (61) admits the following irreducible representation (Pennisi and Trovato, 1987; Smith, 1971; Spencer, 1971)
as function of the minimal set of invariants

where I1, I2, and I3 are purely elastic invariants and I4 is a purely electric invariant, whereas I5 and I6 are mixed electro-elastic invariants. Then, by plugging equation (62) into equation (61), the final form of the free-energy function for thermo-sensitive ITEEPDs is

Accordingly, substituting equation (65) into equations (50) to (52), the required constitutive equations for the electric polarization, the true total stress tensor and the entropy of the considered ITEEPDs can be read as
with ai being the electroelastic coefficients

generally depending on the material invariants defined in equations (63) and (64). Note that in obtaining equation (67), the expression of P given by equation (66) has been directly substituted in the last term of equation (51).

sec.title: Heat flux vector for ITEEPDs
sec.p: Consider the first law of thermodynamics given by equation (44). Substituting equations (50) to (52) therein yields
which is the total balance of TEM energy in entropy (or temperature) form. By the chain rule differentiation on η and using equations (53) and (59), equation (70) can be rewritten as

with υ and ℘ accounting for the structural thermo- elastic heating/cooling effect (therefore, identifying a specific latent heat coefficient of deformation (Holzapfel, 2001)) and for the electro-caloric heating/cooling effect (therefore, identifying a specific pyroelectric coefficient (Neese et al., 2008)), respectively, and having the following expressions

both dependent on the electro-elastic material coefficients defined by equation (69). Equation (71) is the calorimetric equation for ITEEPDs that, together with the boundary condition given by equation (39), governs the evolution of the temperature field Θ as function of direct heat (i.e. R and q) as well as of the variations of both deformation F and electric field E.

As aforementioned, solution of equation (71) requires the definition of a constitutive equation for the heat flux vector in the form given by equation (46). Assuming an isotropic TEM response for the considered ITEEPDs, owing to the representation theorem for invariants (Eringen, 1980; Pennisi and Trovato, 1987; Smith, 1971; Spencer, 1971; Truesdell and Noll, 1992), the heat flux vector can be written as a function of six generators of the variables B, E, and ∇Θ, namely

with the coefficients b1(Θ) and b4(Θ) directly accounting for the isotropic heat conduction and the Peltier effect, respectively, and the coefficient b2(Θ), b3(Θ), b5(Θ), and b6(Θ) representing the remaining deformation-induced anisotropic effects.

sec.title: Specific constitutive equations for compressible EEs
sec.p:
According to the preceding sections, the TEM behavior of any kind of ITEEPD can be studied by plugging the constitutive relations given by equations (66) to (68) and (72) to (74) into the balance relations given by equations (15) to (19) and (71) and by simultaneously solving them for the independent variables u,
ϕ
, and Θ, once the boundary conditions described by equations (20), (21), and (39) are known. In practice, the specific characteristic response of a given material is accounted in these equations by selecting appropriate expressions for the following 15 material coefficients: the six coefficients ai (i = 1, …, 6) of the free-energy function Ψ (see equation (69)), the six coefficients bi (i = 1, …, 6) of the heat flux vector q (see equation (74)), the specific heat capacity c0 (see equation (59)), and the (linear) thermal expansion and the specific bulk modulus coefficients α0 and κ0, respectively.

Among the different kinds of ITEEPDs, EEs are special rubber-like dielectrics that exhibit: a thermal response that is isotropic irrespective of the deformation state and does not feature any Peltier effect; a strain-dependent polarization response that is linear with the electric field, isotropic in a strain-free configuration, and anisotropic otherwise; a hyperelastic mechanical response that is isotropic in the absence of an electric field and anisotropic otherwise. As a result, in the case of EEs, the constitutive equation for the heat flux vector (i.e. equation (74)) simply reduces to the Fourier’s law of heat conduction

where ξ0 is the constant coefficient of thermal conductivity at the reference temperature Θ0 and ω is a softening parameter (Sircar and Wells, 1981), whereas the free-energy function at the reference temperature Θ0 can be decomposed in the following three parts

where: Ψ0hyel is a purely hyperelastic strain energy function for compressible materials (in equation (77) given in the well-known compressible Mooney–Rivlin form (Holzapfel, 2001), whereas different expressions are possible), which depends on the constant material parameters c10, c20, and c30 of the EE as well as on its reference mass density ρ0 (ρ0 = Jρ), all measured at the reference temperature Θ0; Ψ0estr is a purely electrostrictive free-energy function that depends on the constant material parameters β10 and β20, namely the electrostriction coefficients of the EE at the reference temperature Θ0; Ψ0esta is a purely electrostatic free-energy function that depends on the constant material parameter χ0, namely the electric susceptibility of the EE at the reference temperature Θ0. Similar to that mentioned for Ψ0hyel, it is worth noting that Ψ0estr is only one of the possible free-energies characterizing the electrostrictive behavior of a given EE, the other forms being obtainable by the inclusion and/or substitution of additional terms that depend on a mixed combination of the electro-elastic invariants defined by equations (63) and (64).
Accordingly, the constitutive equations for the electric polarization (i.e. equation (66)) and the total stress tensor (i.e. equation (67)) reduce to
where

where χΘ, β1Θ, β2Θ, c1Θ, c2Θ, and c3Θ are the actual electro-elastic material parameters of the EE depending linearly on the actual temperature Θ; εΘ is the actual relative dielectric constant of the EE depending linearly on the actual temperature Θ;
σ
^
M
is the electrostatic stress tensor (i.e. the equivalent form of Maxwell’s stress tensor given by equation (36) for a medium having relative dielectric constant equaling εΘ); and
σ ^
e s t r
is the electrostrictive stress tensor. Regarding the nature of these stresses,
σ ^
M
originates from the change in electric field distribution inside the material with strain (or equivalently from the coulombic interaction between the charges generating the electric field), whereas
σ ^
e s t r
is related to the change in material dielectric properties with strain (Krakovský et al., 1999; Landau and Lifshitz, 1960). Note that in the small-strain approximation, equations (80), (86), and (87) reduce to the well-known formulas proposed by Landau and Lifshitz (1960), with β1Θ and β2Θ respectively describing the variation of the dielectric constant with shear and bulk deformations.

sec.title: Specific constitutive equations for incompressible EEs
sec.p:
In case the considered EEs are mechanically incompressible, the multiplicative split introduced in equations (4) and (6) can be used. Since the considered EEs are thermally isotropic, the thermally induced deformation from the configuration
B
0
at the reference temperature Θ0 to the configuration
B
at the actual temperature Θ is characterized by

Moreover, since in the incompressible case the hydrostatic terms appearing in equations (81), (86), and (87) have no influence on the stress response, the free-energy function given in equations (76) to (79) can be simplified as
with

where now: Ψ0hyel is a hyperelastic strain energy for incompressible materials (in equation (92) given in the well-known incompressible Mooney–Rivlin form (Holzapfel, 2001), whereas different expressions are possible), which is function of the modified strain invariants
I
¯
1
and
I
¯
2
(i.e. the first two invariants of the isochoric Finger’s deformation tensor
B
¯
=
F
¯
F
¯
T
with
F
¯
= F
F
Θ
− 1
= F /
e
α
0
T
) and only dependent on two constant material parameters c10 and c20 such that (c10+c20) = (µ0/2), with µ0 being the shear modulus of the given EE at the reference temperature Θ0; Ψ0estr and Ψ0esta are the electrostrictive and electrostatic free-energies, which depend on the same parameters as for the compressible case (namely β10, β20, and χ0).
Accordingly, in case of incompressible EEs, the constitutive equations for the electric polarization (equation (66)) and the total stress tensor (equation (67)) reduce to
with p being the hydrostatic pressure, which can be determined by the boundary conditions.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As compared to earlier literature, the continuum TEM model described in this article can be considered as: (1) the thermodynamic extension of the electro-elastic formulations proposed by Toupin (1956), Hutter and Van De Ven (1978), Pao (1978), Eringen and Maugin (1990), Dorfmann and Ogden (2005), and McMeeking and Landis (2005, 2007); and (2) the electro-static extension of the entropic thermo-elastic theory proposed by Chadwick and Creasy (1984) and Holzapfel and Simo (1996). In fact, on one hand, the available electro-elastic theories are only adequate to model isothermal processes occurring at a fixed temperature that do not account for any thermo-elastic and electro-caloric heating/cooling effect, and thus implicitly assume that proper heat fluxes exist that keep the considered elastic dielectrics at the uniform reference temperature Θ0. On the other hand, the available thermo-elastic theories are only adequate to model processes that occur in the absence of electrostatic fields, and thus cannot account for the thermo-electric and electro-elastic behaviors of the considered elastic dielectrics.
In extending the existing electro-elastic theories, the following modifications (and/or positions) have been made here:

list-item.p: Different from the studies by Hutter and Van De Ven (1978), Pao (1978), Eringen and Maugin (1990), and Dorfmann and Ogden (2005), the mechanical solicitations of electrostatic origin do not appear explicitly in the balance of linear mechanical momentum (i.e. in equation (16)), and thus, no assumption is made on the existence of an electrostatic body force be with given mathematical expression (for instance, be = div(D⊗E− 0.5ε0E21) as proposed in studies by Einstein and Laub (1908), Tiersten and Tsai (1972), De Groot and Suttorp (1972), and Pao and Hutter (1975); be = div(E⊗E− 0.5ε0E21) as proposed in Fano et al. (1960), Toupin (1963), and Hutter (1977, 1975); or be = div(D⊗E− 0.5ε0E·D1) as proposed in Minkowski (1909), Heaviside (1912), and Moller (1972)). Instead, owing to their conservative nature, all the electrostatic solicitations are here accounted implicitly in the constitutive equation for the stress tensor (i.e. equation (51)), which naturally derives from the total balance of TEM energy.

Different from the studies by Toupin (1956), and similar to the studies by McMeeking and Landis (2005), the electrical power
P
el
is not expressed as the work done by the electric field in changing the polarization of
B
, but is instead more naturally described (see equation (26)) in terms of the work performed by an external agency (for instance, a battery or a power supply) in bringing the infinitesimal charges ϕdv and ϕγds from infinity to points of
B
with given electric potential
ϕ
.

Different from the study performed by McMeeking and Landis (2005) and similar to the one by Toupin (1956), the potential energy
W
of the space contained within
B
also comprises the additional term
D
(see equations (28) to (30)), which can be interpreted as the work that is required to build the electric field E in a space permeated by a constant electric polarization field P (in the literature, the same term
D
is also considered by other authors such as Trimarco (2009)).
The balance equations (15) to (19), (44), and (45) coincide with those presented by Eringen and Maugin (1990) (despite the stress tensor defined therein being different from the one defined here).

Different from the studies by McMeeking and Landis (2005, 2007), by resorting to the fundamental result of potential theory (expressed by equation (22) and described in Figure 2), localization of equation (23) does not require the restriction for the arbitrary subsystem
B
*
of being electrically isolated.

Different from the studies by Toupin (1956) and McMeeking and Landis (2005), which choose the electric polarization P as the independent variable, here, the electric field E is naturally taken as the independent variable since it is more directly related (via equation (18)) to the usually measurable and controllable variable
ϕ
.

Different from the studies by Hutter and Van De Ven (1978), Pao (1978), Eringen and Maugin (1990), and McMeeking and Landis (2005), the additional term E·P is not required in the Legendre transformation given by equation (43), which noticeably eases the thermodynamic extension of the considered electro-elastic model (the presence of the term E·P could indeed yield considerable and unnecessary complications within equations (53) to (61)).

The form of the free-energy function Ψ0 at the reference temperature Θ0 given by equations (62) to (64) is similar to those proposed by Eringen and Maugin (1990) and Dorfmann and Ogden (2005), but owing to the different definition of the total stress tensor adopted therein (i.e. compare with equation (51)), the related constitutive equation results in being slightly different (namely, in the studies by Eringen and Maugin (1990) and Dorfmann and Ogden (2005), the term a6 in equation (67) is multiplied by the matrix 0.5·((B2E) ⊗E+E⊗ (B2E)) instead of the matrix (BE) ⊗ (BE) as it occurs here).

sec.p: Moreover, as compared to all prior studies on electro-elasticity, the general free-energy function Ψ0 given by equations (62) to (64) is here particularized for both compressible and incompressible EEs that are electro-mechanically isotropic in their undeformed configuration and become anisotropic whenever they are subjected to some deformation B and/or electric field E. The specific electrostatic and electrostrictive effects that occur in these kinds of hyperelastic dielectrics are clearly described in equations (80), (81), (86), and (87) for the compressible case and in equations (98) and (99) for the incompressible case, where they are shown to depend naturally on the three coefficients regulating the EE electrical polarizability (namely the electric susceptibility χ0 and the electrostriction coefficients β10 and β20). In practice, equations (80), (81), (86), and (87) and equations (98) and (99) can be considered as the extension to finite deformations of the well-known small-strain theory for isotropic electrostriction proposed by Stratton (1941) and Landau and Lifshitz (1960).

With the modifications described earlier, the proposed TEM model has then been obtained naturally from the thermo-elastic theory of modified-entropic elastomers (Chadwick and Creasy, 1984; Holzapfel and Simo, 1996) by:

list-item.p: consistently making the isothermal free-energy Ψ0 be dependent not only on the deformation invariants but also on the electric and the mixed electro-elastic invariants (see equations (55) to (64));

deriving the calorimetric equation given by equations (71) to (73), which brings in the thermal effects produced by the variation of the electric field (inevitably caused by the pyroelectric coefficient ℘ defined by equation (73)) together with those occurring as a consequence of deformation (inevitably caused by the latent heat coefficient of deformation υ defined by equation (72));
imposing an objective and isotropic constitutive equation for the heat flux vector q (namely, equation (74) for general materials and equation (75) for simpler EEs).

sec.p: By zeroing the electrostriction coefficients β10 and β20 in equations (98) and (99), the proposed theory immediately reduces to a TEM model for the so-called DEs, which are incompressible hyperelastic dielectrics featuring dielectric properties independent of deformation (Carpi et al., 2008). In the context of DE analysis, the reduced version of the proposed model (i.e. equations (98) and (99) with β10 = β20 = 0) differs from the one proposed by Liu et al. (2011) and Sheng et al. (2011) since therein the authors:

list-item.p: do not provide any calorimetric equation similar to equations (71) to (73) and do not provide any constitutive equation for the heat flux vector similar to equations (74) and (75), thus limiting their theory to the study of isothermal processes only;

neglect any thermally induced volumetric expansion (i.e. they consider α0 = 0), which usually plays a significant role in the thermo-elastic response of most elastomeric materials (for instance, see the following section);

employ a Debye model to express the temperature dependency of the dielectric constant that, as compared to equations (98) and (82), is less suited to account for the linear and positive proportionality of the dielectric constant with temperature that is usually exhibited by a large number of elastomeric materials such as NR, SBR, SIS, EPR, and some AR elastomers (Kunanuruksapong and Sirivat, 2008; Saad and Younan, 1995).

sec.p: The proposed TEM model is thermodynamically consistent and highlights the linear and positive dependency of all the electro-mechanical parameters (see equations (82) to (85)) from the actual temperature Θ. However, the model strictly applies to hyperelastic dielectrics with entropic (or modified-entropic) TEM response only as exhibited by NR, SBR, SIS, EPR, and some AR elastomers (Kunanuruksapong and Sirivat, 2008; Saad and Younan, 1995). Besides, it is worth to mention that the proposed model cannot be used (as it is) to predict the TEM response of the 3M acrylic tape VHB-4910 (which is a popular material for building EE transducer prototypes). Indeed, according to experimental data found in the literature (Jean-Mistral et al., 2010; Michel et al., 2010), the VHB-4910 seems to feature both shear modulus and dielectric constant that decrease non-linearly with temperature. However, owing to the consistent discrepancy and low repeatability (by more than 10%) of the electro-mechanical properties measured on this material in different studies, and owing to the moderate coefficient of linear expansion (which may induce temperature-related measurement errors larger than 5% in case the samples are not properly conditioned), more in-depth experimental testing is required prior to modify the proposed theory in order to fit the truly effective TEM response of VHB-4910.

sec.title: Model validation
sec.p: To demonstrate the adequacy of the proposed theory for studying the TEM behavior of practical EEs, a case study is reported in the following.

Virgin membrane samples made of NR loaded with calcium carbonate (CaCO3) were prepared by first mixing and conditioning a mixture of 30 parts of CaCO3 per hundred parts of NR according to the procedures described in the standards ASTM D3184-89 and ASTM D1646, and second by vulcanizing the resulting NR–CaCO3 mixture in a hydraulic press at a temperature of 142°C and a pressure of 4 MPa. The so obtained virgin NR–CaCO3 membranes were then mechanically preconditioned via 20 biaxial loading–unloading cycles with principal stretches up to 4 and 1.5 (say in the orthogonal directions x and y, respectively) so as to eliminate any stress-softening and permanent-set effect (Vertechy et al., 2010; Berselli et al., 2011, 2012).

Afterward, the preconditioned NR–CaCO3 membranes were subjected to dielectric testing using a Novocontrol ALPHA analyzer with two heated parallel plates whose temperature was controlled in the range 20°C–60°C (specifically, these dielectric tests were performed on two sets of NR–CaCO3 membranes with equibiaxial prestretch equaling 1 and 3, respectively). Finally, the analyzed membranes were embedded in the lozenge mechanism reported in Figure 3 and coated on both sides with compliant electrodes (made by a silver-conducting grease, CircuitWorks CW-7100) for subsequent TEM testing through a custom-made tensile stage (consisting in a brushless linear motor (Linmot P01-37x120FH) and a force sensor (Futek LSB200)), which was immersed in a chamber with temperature controlled in the range 20°C–60°C.

caption.p: Electrostrictive elastomer (NR–CaCO3) membrane embedded in a lozenge mechanism for TEM testing.

sec.p: As described in Figure 3, the lozenge device is a four-bar mechanism having links with equal and fixed length l (here l = 100 mm) that are connected by four (almost zero friction) revolute joints. The lozenge configuration is uniquely defined by the variable x that measures the length of one of its diagonals. The mechanism is connected to the tensile stage via two additional output links that can respectively pivot on the two opposite revolute joints laying along the lozenge diagonal measured by the variable x. The NR–CaCO3 membrane is constrained to the lozenge links along its perimeter in a mechanically pretensioned state (here, the principal stretches for the considered NR-CaCO3 membrane are uniform and, at x = x0 = 80 mm, they are equal to λx0 = 0.685 and λy0 = 3.1 along the directions x and y, respectively). Thanks to the lozenge geometry, for any configuration x, the NR–CaCO3 membrane is always in a uniform state of deformation. Application of a voltage difference V (hereafter called activation voltage) between the opposing compliant electrodes generates a uniform electric field across the NR–CaCO3 membrane along the direction z that is orthogonal to the lozenge diagonals x and y. The membrane stresses generated by the principal stretches and the electric field are balanced by the external force f (directed along x) that is provided by the tensile stage on the lozenge output links. More information and optimal design guidelines for EE-based lozenge mechanisms can be found in the study by Vertechy et al. (2010).

The experimental results of the dielectric testing on the considered NR–CaCO3 membranes are plotted with circle markers in Figure 4. The measurements were performed at 0.1 Hz and were normalized by eliminating the contribution arising from the thermal dilation of the NR–CaCO3 membrane that occurs at different temperatures via the (linear) thermal expansion coefficient α0 (here α0 = 2.23 × 10−4 m/(m K) has been chosen in agreement with the study by Holzapfel and Simo (1996)). Specifically, the data shown in Figure 4 refer to a sample with equibiaxial prestretch equaling 1. The tests performed on samples with prestretch equaling 3 did not show significant difference and thus are not reported here. That is, the equivalence β10 = β20 = 0 holds for the considered NR-CaCO3 membranes. Note that the obtained experimental results are in agreement with those described by Saad and Younan (1995). In accordance to equations (82) and (85), Figure 4 highlights a rather linear and positive dependency of the dielectric constant εΘ with the absolute temperature Θ.

caption.p: Dielectric constant at 0.1 Hz of the NR–CaCO3 membrane versus temperature: experimental data (EXP) and analytical results obtained with the proposed model (M1).

sec.p: The experimental results of the TEM testing performed on the same NR-CaCO3 membrane at a constant strain rate of 0.03 per second are given in Figure 5 (EXP lines), which reports the force–length (f–x) curves of the lozenge mechanism, shown in Figure 3, for different activation voltages (marked with circles for V = 0 and with squares for V = 10 kV) and for different ambient temperatures (EXP red line for Θ = 293 K, EXP black line for Θ = 313 K, and EXP blue line for Θ = 333 K). Specifically, Figure 5 highlights that both voltage and temperature increases cause a downward shift of the measured lozenge force–length curves.

caption.p: Force–length curves of the NR–CaCO3 membrane measured at a strain rate of 0.03 per second for different temperatures and different activation voltages: experimental data (EXP), analytical result obtained with the proposed model (M1), and analytical result obtained with a model from the literature (M2).

sec.p: Following dielectric and TEM testing, the obtained experimental data have been used for the validation of the theoretical model described in the preceding sections. First, using equations (91) to (97) with the kinematic quantities

the following explicit analytical models (hereafter called M1) for the dielectric constant in the z direction, namely,
ε
Θ
z
( x , Θ )
, and the lozenge force, namely, f (x,Θ,V), are obtained

where u0 is the thickness of the NR–CaCO3 membrane in its undeformed configuration (here u0 = 0.84 mm according to experimental measurements performed on the sample depicted in Figure 3). Second, given equations (104) and (105), the material parameters β10, β20, χ0, c10, and c20, have been determined from the experimental data acquired at the reference temperature Θ0 = 313 K (as stated earlier, α0 has been chosen in agreement with the study by Holzapfel and Simo (1996)). Specifically: β10 and β20 have been chosen in agreement with the results from the dielectric testing, which have been discussed earlier; χ0 has been directly chosen from the experimental value of
ε
Θ
z
(
Θ
0
)
that is reported in Figure 4; c10 and c20 have been determined by fitting equation (105) to the experimental f–x curve obtained for Θ0 = 313 K and V = 0 (curve plotted in Figure 5). The resulting material constants are as follows

Then, using these parameters, equation (104) with the temperature Θ varying in the range of 293–333 K is plotted in Figure 4 against the experimental results (EXP), whereas equation (105) with the lozenge length x varying in the range of 80–100 mm is plotted in Figure 5 against the experimental results (EXP) for two different voltages V = 0 kV (M1 solid line) and V = 10 kV (M1 dash-dotted line) and for three different temperatures Θ = 293 K (M1 red line), Θ = 313 K (M1 black line), and Θ = 333 K (M1 blue line). As shown, the analytical predictions (M1) and experimental results (EXP) match very well, indicating that the proposed theory is adequate for the TEM analysis of modified-entropic EEs similar to the considered NR–CaCO3 membrane.

To show the importance of including within the TEM model, the volumetric dilation described by α0 (which was instead neglected in previous studies by Liu et al. (2011) and Sheng et al. (2011)), a second model (hereafter indicated with M2) employing equation (105) with α0 = 0 is also plotted in Figure 5 for two different voltages V = 0 kV (M2 line with dot markers) and V = 10 kV (M2 line with asterisk markers) and for three different temperatures Θ = 293 K (M2 magenta line), Θ = 313 K (M2 gray line), and Θ = 333 K (M2 cyan line). As shown, this second model adequately predicts the experimental data at the reference temperature Θ =Θ0 only, whereas deviations occur at other temperatures, which highlights that the theory proposed here is more adequate than that presented by Liu et al. (2011) and Sheng et al. (2011) for the TEM analysis of modified-entropic EEs similar to the considered NR–CaCO3.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article presented a fully coupled thermo-electro-mechanical continuum model for the study of the thermo-electro-elastic large deformations of general EEs, which are isotropic in their undeformed and electrically deactivated state. The model comprises the standard equilibrium equations of both electrostatics, finite elasticity, and calorimetry, along with their associated boundary conditions, and specific phenomenological invariant-based thermo- electro-hyperelastic constitutive equations that account for all the coupling effects that may arise from the interaction between thermo-elastic dielectrics, electrostatic fields, and thermal fields. Comparison with existing models and experimental results were provided that validate the proposed theory.

ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the support provided by the Italian Ministry of University and Research.
